content:
🌍 MARKET NEWS RECAP

**🌍 MARKET OVERVIEW**
Asian markets were mixed in quiet trading, though China's $Shanghai Composite posted a modest gain of 0.3% despite rising geopolitical tensions related to military drills near Taiwan. European stock futures are pointing slightly higher as the region resumes trading for a shortened holiday week, with the $Euro Stoxx 50 expected to open with a positive bias. US equity futures are largely flat in thin pre-market trade, following the previous week's record highs. In commodities, crude oil advanced, with Brent crude topping $60 per barrel, while silver continued its recent rally with a 3% jump.

**💼 PORTFOLIO FOCUS**
The AI/Semiconductor sector remains a key driver, with SEMI projecting global equipment sales to reach a record $133 billion in 2025, providing a strong tailwind for $NVDA, $TSM, $AVGO, and $SNPS. $TSM is specifically highlighted as a critical and well-positioned 'neutral' supplier in the AI build-out, expected to benefit from massive

🌍 MARKET NEWS RECAP

USA markets are poised for a quiet open with $S&P 500 futures little changed and $NDAQ 100 futures slipping 0.2% in holiday-thinned trading following last week's rally. Asian equities were mixed, but China's $Shanghai Composite posted a modest gain of 0.4% as year-end flows continued. European stock futures point to a slightly higher open, with $Euro Stoxx 50 futures up 0.3%. The commodity sector saw dramatic movement as silver surged to a new all-time high, while gold pulled back more than 1% after reaching a fresh peak in the prior session.

💼 PORTFOLIO FOCUS

Semiconductor and AI-related stocks remain a central focus, with $TSM hitting a record high today after reports indicated the contract chipmaker will raise prices for its high-end chips starting January 1st due to tight global supply. The long-term outlook for the sector is exceptionally strong, with Bank of America forecasting a 30% jump in global semiconductor revenue in 2026, driven by AI infrastructure

🌍 MARKET NEWS RECAP

**🌍 MARKET OVERVIEW**
Global equities are muted in holiday-thinned trading as the year-end "Santa Claus rally" takes a pause. US stock futures are slightly lower, with $NDAQ 100 futures slipping 0.2% after a strong run last week, while $S&P 500 futures remain little changed. European markets are pointing cautiously higher as $Euro Stoxx 50 futures advanced 0.3% in early trading. In Asia, the $Shanghai Composite was virtually unchanged, but the broader MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 0.3%, boosted by tech and industrials.

**💼 PORTFOLIO FOCUS**
The AI/Semiconductor complex remains a key focus, with $AVGO reporting a backlog for its AI switches exceeding $10 billion, driven by record demand for its latest Tomahawk 6 chip. $NVDA is also in the spotlight following a new strategic, non-exclusive license agreement with AI chipmaker Groq, a move valued up to $20 billion to integrate Groq’s inference technology and enhance its position in the AI ecosystem. 🌍 MARKET NEWS RECAP

Global equities began the week mixed in quiet, holiday-thinned trading, as investors consolidated gains from a strong year-end rally. US $S&P 500 futures slipped 0.2% ahead of the open, while European stock futures pointed slightly higher. Asia saw mixed results, with China's $Shanghai Composite flat, but roaring AI demand helped South Korea's Kospi index jump 2.2%. Macro data confirmed China's trade resilience, with its total trade surplus hitting a record $1 trillion this year, driven by robust exports to the EU and African markets.

💼 PORTFOLIO FOCUS

The AI and semiconductor complex remains a key focus for investors, with $NVDA, $AVGO, and $TSM continuing to benefit from the "roaring AI demand" highlighted in fresh global trade reports. Healthcare names $LLY and $NOVO-B are navigating an increasingly competitive GLP-1 market, with recent analyst reports citing the risk of knockoff versions and intense rivalry pressuring guidance. 🌍 MARKET NEWS RECAP

US stock futures are pointing lower to begin the holiday-shortened week, with $S&P 500 futures down 0.3% and $NDAQ 100 futures slipping 0.5% as investors lock in recent gains. European markets were muted and mixed in quiet trading, with the FTSE 100 up slightly while the $DAX 40 remained flat. In China, the government announced it will lower provisional import tariff rates on 935 products, including advanced materials and medical goods, starting in 2026 to boost high-quality domestic supply.

💼 PORTFOLIO FOCUS

The Technology sector is seeing profit-taking, with AI leader $NVDA pulling back about 2% in early trading, alongside modest declines for other mega-cap and semiconductor names like $AVGO and $TSM. The Healthcare sector remains in focus as $LLY and $NOVO-B.CO continue to dominate headlines regarding GLP-1 drug competition and oral delivery innovation.
